But doesn’t Rabbi Shmuel say Rabbi Ḥanina says: one who purchases untithed produce from a gentile smoothed he tithes but they are his,
llm_translation: Sitting Rav Dimi and saying to him Abaye: Reason of that we are in doubt if we exchanged them or not exchanged them, this and certainly we exchanged them - for everyone in the world needs to give to the priest, and Rabbi Shmuel said Rabbi Chanina: One who takes tevel from a gentile, we tithe it and it is his!

hebrew_text: דִּלְמָא כָּאן בִּתְרוּמָה גְּדוֹלָה, כָּאן בִּתְרוּמַת מַעֲשֵׂר!
human_translation: Perhaps here, to teruma gedola , there, to teruma the tithe.
llm_translation: Perhaps here in a large terumah, here in the terumah of ma'aser!

hebrew_text: אַזְכַּרְתַּן מִילְּתָא דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: מִנַּיִן לַלּוֹקֵחַ טְבָלִים מְמוֹרָחִין מִן הַגּוֹי שֶׁהוּא פָּטוּר מִתְּרוּמַת מַעֲשֵׂר? שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְאֶל הַלְוִיִּם תְּדַבֵּר וְאָמַרְתָּ אֲלֵיהֶם כִּי תִקְחוּ מֵאֵת בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״, טְבָלִים שֶׁאַתָּה לוֹקֵחַ מִבְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל — אַתָּה מַפְרִישׁ מֵהֶן תְּרוּמַת מַעֲשֵׂר וְנוֹתְנָהּ לַכֹּהֵן, טְבָלִים שֶׁאַתָּה לוֹקֵחַ מִן הַגּוֹי — אִי אַתָּה מַפְרִישׁ מֵהֶן תְּרוּמַת מַעֲשֵׂר וְנוֹתְנָהּ לַכֹּהֵן.
human_translation: You reminded me of a statement that Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: From where that one who purchases from a gentile untithed produce smoothed is exempt from teruma of the tithe? as it is stated: “And you shall speak to the Levites, and say to them: When you take the children of Israel untithed produce that you purchase from the children of Israel, you separate teruma of the tithe from it and give to a priest, untithed produce that you purchase from a gentile, you do not separate teruma of the tithe from it and give it to a priest.
llm_translation: I will remember the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: From where do we derive that one who purchases produce from a non-Jew, who is exempt from tithing, must separate tithes? As it is stated: "And to the Levites you shall speak, and you shall say to them: When you take from the children of Israel," tithes that you take from the children of Israel—you separate from them the tithe and give it to the kohen. Tithes that you take from a non-Jew—you do not separate the tithe from it and give it to the kohen.

hebrew_text: וְאִם מֵת נֶהֱנִים בּוֹ. דְּמִית הֵיכָא? אִילֵּימָא דְּמִית בֵּי כֹהֵן, וְנֶהֱנֶה בּוֹ כֹּהֵן — פְּשִׁיטָא, מָמוֹנָא דִּידֵיהּ הוּא! אֶלָּא, דְּמִית בֵּי בְעָלִים וְנֶהֱנֶה בּוֹ כֹּהֵן — הָא נָמֵי פְּשִׁיטָא!
human_translation: And if it dies, one may derive benefit from it. Where did it die? If we say that it died the house of the priest, and the priest may derive benefit from it, obvious? is his property. Rather, that it died the house of the owner and the priest may derive benefit from it. this also obvious?
llm_translation: If he died, they benefit from him. Where is this comparison? If you say it is a comparison to the house of a priest, and a priest benefits from it - it is obvious, it is his own money! Rather, if it is a comparison to the house of owners, and a priest benefits from it - that is indeed obvious!

hebrew_text: סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא, כֹּל כַּמָּה דְּלָא מְטָא לִידֵיהּ לָא זְכָה בֵּיהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּמֵעִידָּנָא דְּאַפְרְשֵׁיהּ, בִּרְשׁוּתֵיהּ דְּכֹהֵן קָאֵי.
human_translation: enter your mind to say as long as has not reached the possession of has not acquired it. teaches us that from the time that separated it, it stands in the possession of the priest.
llm_translation: I would say, whatever does not come into his possession, he did not acquire it, we learn that we testify that we explain, with the permission of the priest he stands.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֵין פּוֹדִין לֹא בְּעֵגֶל וְלֹא בְּחַיָּה, לֹא בִּשְׁחוּטָה וְלֹא בִּטְרֵיפָה, וְלֹא בְּכִלְאַיִם וְלֹא בְּכוֹי. וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר מַתִּיר בַּכִּלְאַיִם מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא שֶׂה, וְאוֹסֵר בַּכּוֹי מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא סָפֵק. נְתָנוֹ לְכֹהֵן — אֵין הַכֹּהֵן רַשַּׁאי לְקַיְּימוֹ עַד שֶׁיַּפְרִישׁ שֶׂה תַּחְתָּיו.
human_translation: One may not redeem neither with a calf, nor with an undomesticated animal, nor with a slaughtered nor with a tereifa , nor with a hybrid nor with a koy , And Rabbi Eliezer deems it permitted with a hybrid because it is a lamb, but prohibits with a koy , because its uncertain. gave to a priest, the priest may not keep it unless designates a lamb in its stead
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One may not redeem with a calf or with a beast, neither with a slaughtered animal nor with a treifah, not with mixed species nor with a blemish. Rabbi Eliezer permits redemption with mixed species because it is a sheep, and prohibits redemption with a blemish due to uncertainty. If one gives it to a priest, the priest is not permitted to fulfill it until he designates a sheep in its place.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַתְנִיתִין מַנִּי? בֶּן בַּג בַּג הִיא, דְּתַנְיָא: בֶּן בַּג בַּג אוֹמֵר: נֶאֱמַר כָּאן ״שֶׂה״, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן ״שֶׂה״, מָה לְּהַלָּן פְּרָט לְכׇל הַשֵּׁמוֹת הַלָּלוּ, אַף כָּאן פְּרָט לְכׇל הַשֵּׁמוֹת הַלָּלוּ.
human_translation: Whose the mishna? It is ben Bag Bag, as it is taught ben Bag Bag says: It is stated here, a lamb” and it is stated there, a lamb” just as there, excludes all of these names, so too here, excludes all of these names.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara: Matnitin Mani? Ben Bag Bag Hi, detanya: Ben Bag Bag omer: Ne'emar kan "seh," v'ne'emar lehalan "seh," mah lehalan perat lekol hashemot hallu, af kan perat lekol hashemot hallu. English translation: Gemara: From where do we derive this teaching? It is Ben Bag Bag, as it was taught: Ben Bag Bag says: It is stated here "lamb," and it is stated there "lamb," just as there it is a specification for all these names, so too here it is a specification for all these names.

hebrew_text: אִי מָה לְהַלָּן זָכָר תָּמִים וּבֶן שָׁנָה, אַף כָּאן זָכָר תָּמִים וּבֶן שָׁנָה? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״תִּפְדֶּה״ ״תִּפְדֶּה״ — רִיבָּה.
human_translation: If just as there, male, unblemished, and in its year so too here, male, unblemished, and in its year. the verse states: “You shall redeem” “You shall redeem” include
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Just as there, "male without blemish, a yearling," so too here, "male without blemish, a yearling"? The Torah teaches: "You shall redeem," "You shall redeem" - it is a dispute.

hebrew_text: אִי ״תִּפְדֶּה״ ״תִּפְדֶּה״ רִיבָּה, אֲפִילּוּ כֹּל הָנֵי נָמֵי? אִם כֵּן, ״שֶׂה״ ״שֶׂה״ מַאי אַהֲנִי לֵיהּ?
human_translation: If “you shall redeem,” “you shall redeem,” include, even all of these If so, what purpose does “lamb,” “lamb,” serve?
llm_translation: "If 'redeem' redeem doubled, does it apply even to all these coins? If so, what does 'lamb' 'lamb' benefit it?"

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: מַהוּ לִפְדּוֹת בְּבֶן פְּקוּעָה? אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, דְּכֵיוָן דְּאָמַר רַבִּי מֵאִיר: בֶּן פְּקוּעָה טָעוּן שְׁחִיטָה, שֶׂה מְעַלְּיָא הוּא. אֶלָּא כִּי תִּבְּעֵי לָךְ אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבָּנַן, דְּאָמְרִי: שְׁחִיטַת אִמּוֹ מְטַהַרְתּוֹ.
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before What is with regard to redeeming with that was removed from its mother’s womb after the mother was ritually slaughtered [ ben pekua ]? According to of Rabbi Meir you should not raise the dilemma, as since Rabbi Meir says a ben pekua requires slaughter, it is a full-fledged lamb. Rather, you should raise the dilemma according to of the Rabbis, who say the slaughter of its mother renders permitted
llm_translation: He asked them: What about redeeming a firstborn donkey? According to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, he will not ask you, for since Rabbi Meir said: A firstborn donkey requires ritual slaughter, it is considered an elevation offering. Rather, if you were to ask according to the opinion of the Rabbis, who say: The slaughter of its mother purifies it.

hebrew_text: כְּבִישְׂרָא בְּדִיקּוּלָא דָּמֵי, אוֹ דִלְמָא: כֵּיוָן דְּהַשְׁתָּא מִיהָא רָהֵיט וְאָזֵיל, ״שֶׂה״ קָרֵינָא בֵּיהּ?
human_translation: like meat in a pot, Or perhaps since now, in any event, it runs along, we call it a lamb.
llm_translation: As for Kivisra in the village of Dikula, is it similar, or perhaps: since now it is moist and flowing, is it called "Seh"?

hebrew_text: מָר זוּטְרָא אָמַר: אֵין פּוֹדִין, וְרַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: פּוֹדִין.
human_translation: Mar Zutra said one may not redeem and Rav Ashi said one may redeem
llm_translation: Mar Zutra said: We do not redeem, and Rav Ashi said: We redeem.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב אָשֵׁי לְמָר זוּטְרָא: מַאי דַּעְתָּיךְ? דְּיָלְפַתְּ מִפֶּסַח. אִי מָה לְהַלָּן זָכָר תָּמִים וּבֶן שָׁנָה, אַף כָּאן זָכָר תָּמִים וּבֶן שָׁנָה! ״תִּפְדֶּה״ ״תִּפְדֶּה״ — רִיבָּה.
human_translation: Rav Ashi said to Mar Zutra: What your opinion? because you derive from the Paschal offering, If just as there, male, unblemished, and in its year, so too here, male, unblemished, and in its year. “you shall redeem,” “you shall redeem,” included
llm_translation: He said to him Rav Ashe to Mar Zutra: What is your opinion? That it should be different from Pesach. If there it is a male lamb, unblemished, and a year old, so too here it should be a male lamb, unblemished, and a year old! "You shall redeem" "You shall redeem" - it is a dispute.

hebrew_text: אִי ״תִּפְדֶּה״ ״תִּפְדֶּה״ רִיבָּה, אֲפִילּוּ בֶּן פְּקוּעָה נָמֵי! אִם כֵּן, ״שֶׂה״ ״שֶׂה״ מַאי אַהֲנִי לֵיהּ?
human_translation: If “you shall redeem,” “you shall redeem,” included even a ben pekua If so, what purpose does “lamb,” “lamb,” serve?
llm_translation: If "redeem" redeem interest, even a son of a prostitute agrees! If so, what does "lamb" "lamb" help him?

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: מַהוּ לִפְדּוֹת בְּנִדְמָה? אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, הַשְׁתָּא בְּכִלְאַיִם פָּרְקִינַן, בְּנִדְמָה מִיבַּעְיָא?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before What is with regard to redeeming with resembles According to of Rabbi Eliezer, do not raise the dilemma, now one may redeem with a hybrid with regard to resembles is necessary
llm_translation: He asked them: What is the law regarding redeeming with a substitute? According to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, he does not ask you, now we are dealing with two separate matters, what is the law regarding redeeming with a substitute?

hebrew_text: כִּי תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבָּנַן, בְּכִלְאַיִם הוּא דְּלָא פָּרְקִינַן, בְּנִדְמָה פָּרְקִינַן, אוֹ דִלְמָא לָא שְׁנָא?
human_translation: when should you raise the dilemma? according to of the Rabbis, one does not redeem with a hybrid one does redeem with resembles Or perhaps no difference
llm_translation: When you want to argue with the words of the Sages, it is in two ways that we do not differentiate: whether it is in a case of monetary law or in a case of a capital offense, or perhaps it is not different?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: פָּרָה שֶׁיָּלְדָה מִין עֵז — אֵין פּוֹדִין, הָא רָחֵל שֶׁיָּלְדָה מִין עֵז — פּוֹדִין. מַנִּי? אִילֵימָא רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר — הָא בְּכִלְאַיִם נָמֵי פָּרְקִינַן! אֶלָּא לָאו רַבָּנַן הִיא?
human_translation: Come hear a cow that gave birth to a goat of sorts, one may not redeem But a ewe that gave birth to a goat of sorts, one may redeem Whose If we say Rabbi Eliezer, one may redeem even with a hybrid Rather, is it not the Rabbis,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Come and hear: If a cow gives birth to a kid — we do not redeem it, but if Rachel gives birth to a kid — we redeem it. What is the reason? If you say it is according to Rabbi Eliezer — but in the case of mixed species, do we indeed redeem it! Rather, is it not according to the Rabbis?"

hebrew_text: לָא, לְעוֹלָם רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר הִיא, גּוּפַהּ קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּפָרָה שֶׁיָּלְדָה מִין עֵז — אֵין פּוֹדִין. לָא תֵּימָא: זִיל אַבָּתְרֵיהּ דִּידֵיהּ, וְהַאי עֵז מְעַלְּיָא הוּא, אֶלָּא זִיל בָּתַר אִימֵּיהּ — וְהַאי עֵגֶל הוּא.
human_translation: No, actually Rabbi Eliezer, teaches us the itself that one may not redeem where a cow gave birth to a goat of sorts, do not say follow itself, and this is a full-fledged goat Rather, follow its mother, and this is a calf,
llm_translation: No, indeed, Rabbi Eliezer it is always, its body is indicating to us that if a cow gave birth to a kid — we do not redeem. Do not say: Go after its father, and this kid is superior, rather go after its mother — and this is a calf.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּתָנֵי רַבָּה בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל: אֵיזֶהוּ כִּלְאַיִם? רָחֵל שֶׁיָּלְדָה מִין עֵז, וְאָבִיו שֶׂה. אָבִיו שֶׂה, כִּלְאַיִם הוּא? נִדְמֶה הוּא! אֶלָּא, אֵיזֶהוּ דָּמֵי לְכִלְאַיִם, דְּשַׁוְּיוּהּ רַבָּנַן כִּי כִלְאַיִם? רָחֵל שֶׁיָּלְדָה מִין עֵז, וְאָבִיו שֶׂה.
human_translation: Come hear that Rabba bar Shmuel teaches: What is a hybrid? a ewe that gave birth to a goat of sorts and the father of is a lamb. its father a lamb, is a hybrid? It is resembles Rather, What is similar to a hybrid, the Rabbis rendered it tantamount to a hybrid, a ewe that gave birth to a goat of sorts and its father is a lamb.
llm_translation: Come and hear, for Rabba bar Shmuel teaches: What is Kil'ayim? Rachel gave birth from a goat, and its father was a sheep. Its father was a sheep, is it Kil'ayim? It appears so! Rather, what is similar to Kil'ayim, that the Rabbis compared it to Kil'ayim? Rachel gave birth from a goat, and its father was a sheep.

hebrew_text: לְמַאי? אִי לְקָדָשִׁים — מֵהֵיכָא דִּמְמַעֵט כִּלְאַיִם, מֵהָתָם מְמַעֵט נִדְמֶה, דְּתַנְיָא: ״שׁוֹר אוֹ כֶשֶׂב״ — פְּרָט לְכִלְאַיִם, ״אוֹ עֵז״ — פְּרָט לְנִדְמֶה!
human_translation: to what If to sacrificial From where excludes a hybrid it excludes resembles As it is taught “a bull, or a lamb” excluding a hybrid, “or a goat” excluding resembles
llm_translation: For what? If for holy things - from where is it derived that it excludes hybrids? From there it is derived that it appears to exclude, as it was taught: "An ox or a sheep" - excluding hybrids, "or a goat" - excluding what appears to be a hybrid!

hebrew_text: אִי לִבְכוֹר, ״אַךְ בְּכוֹר שׁוֹר״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא, עַד שֶׁיְּהֵא הוּא שׁוֹר וּבְכוֹרוֹ שׁוֹר!
human_translation: If to a firstborn the Merciful One states: “But the firstborn of an ox” only if it is an ox and its firstborn is an ox,
llm_translation: If regarding firstborn, "only firstborn ox" said the Merciful One, until it is an ox and its firstborn is an ox!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לְמַעֲשֵׂר, ״תַּחַת״ ״תַּחַת״ מִקֳּדָשִׁים גָּמַר! אֶלָּא לְפֶטֶר חֲמוֹר.
human_translation: Rather, to tithe derived from “Under” sacrificial “Under” Rather, to a firstborn donkey,
llm_translation: Rather, regarding tithing, "under" "under" from sanctified items is concluded! Rather, regarding exempting a donkey.

hebrew_text: לָא, לְעוֹלָם לְמַעֲשֵׂר, וּכְגוֹן שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ מִקְצָת סִימָנִין, מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא ״הַעֲבָרָה״ ״הַעֲבָרָה״ מִבְּכוֹר גָּמַר,
human_translation: No, actually to tithe where has some characteristics lest you say derived Passing, Passing, a firstborn
llm_translation: Not, always for tithe, and for example that there is in it some signs, what you may say "transgression" "transgression" from firstborn concluded.

hebrew_text: קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן, ״תַּחַת״ ״תַּחַת״ מִקֳּדָשִׁים גָּמַר.
human_translation: teaches us derived from “under” sacrificial “under”
llm_translation: We have heard, "under" "under" from the Holy of Holies concluded.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: מַהוּ לִפְדּוֹת בִּפְסוּלֵי הַמּוּקְדָּשִׁין?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before What is with regard to redeeming with disqualified consecrated
llm_translation: He asked them: What is the law regarding redeeming with disqualified consecrated items?

hebrew_text: אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה — חוּלִּין הוּא, כִּי תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה דְּאָמַר אָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה.
human_translation: According to of Rabbi Shimon, you should not raise the dilemma. Since he says permitted to benefit is non-sacred, When should you raise the dilemma? according to of Rabbi Yehuda, who says prohibited to benefit
llm_translation: In the school of Rabbi Shimon, it is not necessary for you, since he said it is permitted for benefit - it is ordinary. If you require it, in the school of Rabbi Yehuda, who said it is forbidden for benefit.

hebrew_text: מַאי? כֵּיוָן דְּאָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה, אֵין אִיסּוּר חָל עַל אִיסּוּר?
human_translation: What since prohibited to benefit from a prohibition does not take effect prohibition
llm_translation: What? Since it is prohibited to derive benefit, does one prohibition take effect on another prohibition?

hebrew_text: אוֹ דִלְמָא, כֵּיוָן דְּלָא תָּפֵיס פִּדְיוֹנוֹ, אַפְקוֹעֵי אִיסּוּרָא בְּעָלְמָא הוּא?
human_translation: Or perhaps since is not transferred to its redemption, merely an abrogation of forbidden status.
llm_translation: Or perhaps, since he did not accept his redemption, is the prohibition itself merely a general prohibition?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב מָרִי בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב כָּהֲנָא: מִי זוּטַר מַאי דִּכְתִיב בְּהוּ, ״כַּצְּבִי וְכָאַיָּל״? מָה צְבִי וְאַיָּל אֵין פּוֹדִין, אַף פְּסוּלֵי הַמּוּקְדָּשִׁין אֵין פּוֹדִין!
human_translation: Rav Mari, son of Rav Kahana, says: Is that which is written with regard to insignificant? “Like the gazelle and like the hart” just as one may not redeem a gazelle or a hart, so too, one may not redeem disqualified consecrated
llm_translation: Rav Mari, son of Rav Kahana, said: Who is Zutar that is mentioned in the verse, "like a deer and like a gazelle"? Just as deer and gazelles are not redeemed, so too disqualified consecrated items are not redeemed!

hebrew_text: הַשְׁתָּא דְּאָתֵית לְהָכִי,
human_translation: Now that you have arrived at this
llm_translation: The time that it came to this,

hebrew_text: לְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן נָמֵי, ״צְבִי וְאַיָּל״ כְּתִיב בְּהוּ.
human_translation: according to Rabbi Shimon as well, it is written with regard to them the gazelle and the hart”
llm_translation: To Rabbi Shimon the son of Nami, "a deer and a ram" is written in it.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: מַהוּ לִפְדּוֹת בְּבֶהֱמַת שְׁבִיעִית?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before What is with regard to redeeming with an animal of the Sabbatical
llm_translation: He asked them: What is the law regarding redeeming a seventh-year animal?

hebrew_text: וַדַּאי — לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, לַאֲכִילָה אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא, וְלֹא לִסְחוֹרָה. כִּי תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ — סָפֵק.
human_translation: definite you should not raise the dilemma, the Merciful One states for consumption but not for commerce. when should you raise the dilemma? uncertain
llm_translation: Certainly—do not ask for yourself, regarding eating, the Merciful One said, and not for trading. If you ask for yourself—it is doubtful.

hebrew_text: וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן לָא תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ, דְּלֵית לֵיהּ סָפֵק, כִּי תִּיבְּעֵי לָךְ אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: And according to of Rabbi Shimon you should not raise the dilemma, as he does not hold uncertain When should you raise the dilemma? according to of Rabbi Yehuda,
llm_translation: In the matter of Rabbi Shimon, do not ask for yourself, for there is no doubt. When you ask for yourself, ask in the matter of Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: מַאי כֵּיוָן דְּמַפְרֵישׁ טָלֶה וְהוּא לְעַצְמוֹ, ״לְאׇכְלָה״ קָרֵינָא בֵּיהּ, אוֹ דִילְמָא: כֵּיוָן דְּכַמָּה דְּלָא מַפְקַע אִיסּוּרֵיהּ לָא מִישְׁתְּרֵי, כִּסְחוֹרָה דָּמֵי?
human_translation: What since he designates a lamb and it is his, we call “for consumption,” Or perhaps, since as long as does not abrogate the forbidden status of it is not permitted it is tantamount to commerce
llm_translation: What is the reason that when one separates a lamb for itself, we call it "for consumption"? Or perhaps, since as long as he does not remove its prohibitions, it is not considered permitted, is it similar to a business transaction?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: בֶּהֱמַת שְׁבִיעִית אֵין פּוֹדִין בָּהּ אֶת הַוַּדַּאי, אֲבָל פּוֹדִין בָּהּ אֶת הַסָּפֵק.
human_translation: Come hear which Rav Ḥisda says: One may not redeem definite with an animal of the Sabbatical but one may redeem uncertain with it.
llm_translation: Come and hear, for Rav Ḥisda said: In the Sabbatical Year animal, one does not redeem the definite consecrated animal in it, but one does redeem the doubtful consecrated animal in it.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: בֶּהֱמַת שְׁבִיעִית פְּטוּרָה מִן הַבְּכוֹרָה, וְחַיֶּיבֶת בַּמַּתָּנוֹת.
human_translation: And Rav Ḥisda says An animal of the Sabbatical exempt from a firstborn, but is obligated to gifts
llm_translation: And Rav Hisda said: In the seventh-year animal, exempt from the firstborn, and obligated in gifts.

hebrew_text: פְּטוּרָה מִן הַבְּכוֹרָה — ״לְאׇכְלָה״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא, וְלֹא לִשְׂרֵיפָה, וְחַיֶּיבֶת בַּמַּתָּנוֹת — דִּ״לְאָכְלָה״ קָרֵינָא בַּהּ.
human_translation: exempt from a firstborn the Merciful One states “for consumption,” but not for burning, And it is obligated to gifts because we call “for consumption,”
llm_translation: Exemption from the firstborn — "for eating" said the Merciful One, and not for burning, and she is obligated in gifts — because "for eating" is mentioned in it.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: הָאוֹכֵל מֵעִיסַּת שְׁבִיעִית עַד שֶׁלֹּא הוּרְמָה חַלָּתָהּ — חַיָּיב מִיתָה.
human_translation: raises an objection One who eats from dough of Sabbatical before its ḥalla , has been separated, is liable death
llm_translation: Challenger: One who eats from the dough of the seventh year before its separation is liable to death.

hebrew_text: וְאַמַּאי? כֵּיוָן דְּאִילּוּ מִטַּמְּיָא בַּת שְׂרֵיפָה הִיא, ״לְאׇכְלָה״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא, וְלֹא לִשְׂרֵיפָה!
human_translation: But why since if becomes ritually impure it is subject to burning, the Merciful One states: “For consumption,” but not for burning.
llm_translation: And why? Since if from the depths of the fiery furnace she is, "for eating" said the Merciful One, and not for burning!

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי הָכָא, דִּכְתִיב ״לְדוֹרוֹתֵיכֶם״.
human_translation: Here, it is different, as it is written: throughout your generations”
llm_translation: The years here, as it is written "for your generations."

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: מִנַּיִן לָאוֹכֵל מֵעִיסַּת שְׁבִיעִית עַד שֶׁלֹּא הוּרְמָה חַלָּתָהּ שֶׁחַיָּיב מִיתָה — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לְדֹרֹתֵיכֶם״.
human_translation: This is also taught From where that one who consumes dough of Sabbatical before its ḥalla was separated is liable death as it is stated: “Throughout your generations,”
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: How do we know that one may eat from the produce of the seventh year until its dough is separated, and if one eats it, they are liable to receive the death penalty? Because it is stated: "For your generations."

hebrew_text: וְלִגְמַר מִינַּהּ! הָתָם עִיקָּר לַאֲכִילָה, הָכָא עִיקָּר לִשְׂרֵיפָה.
human_translation: And let derive from There, primary for consumption, Here, primary for burning.
llm_translation: And to finish its kind! There, the main purpose is for eating, here the main purpose is for burning.

hebrew_text: נְתָנוֹ לְכֹהֵן כּוּ׳. תְּנֵינָא לְהָא דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: יִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁהָיָה לוֹ פֶּטֶר חֲמוֹר בְּתוֹךְ בֵּיתוֹ, וְאָמַר לוֹ הַכֹּהֵן: ״תְּנֵהוּ לִי וַאֲנִי אֶפְדֵּהוּ״ — הֲרֵי זֶה לֹא יִתְּנוּ לוֹ, אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן פְּדָאוֹ בְּפָנָיו.
human_translation: gave to a priest, We learn that which the Sages taught an Israelite who had a firstborn donkey in his house and the priest said to him: Give it to me and I will redeem it, he may not give to unless redeems it in his presence.
llm_translation: They gave it to the Kohen. We learned in the Mishnah that the Rabbis taught: If an Israelite had a firstborn donkey in his house, and the Kohen said to him, "Give it to me, and I will redeem it," he should not give it to him unless he has already redeemed it before him.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר אֲבוּהּ: זֹאת אוֹמֶרֶת נֶחְשְׁדוּ הַכֹּהֲנִים עַל פִּטְרֵי חֲמוֹרִים. פְּשִׁיטָא! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא: הָנֵי מִילֵּי הֵיכָא דְּמַחְזַק לַן דְּמִיקְּרֵי, אֲבָל בִּסְתָמָא לָא — קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּמוֹרֵה בַּהּ הֶיתֵּירָא.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman says Rabba bar Avuh says: That is to say priests are suspect with regard to firstborn donkeys obvious? lest you say this statement where we have a presumption that it happens but in an ordinary no teaches us that as granting permission
llm_translation: Rav Nachman said, Rabba bar Avuh said: This means the priests were suspected regarding the loaves of donkeys. Obviously! What might you say: those matters where it is established for us that they are called, but in general, no — it is heard for us that it is permitted.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הַמַּפְרִישׁ פִּדְיוֹן פֶּטֶר חֲמוֹר וָמֵת, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: חַיָּיבִין בְּאַחְרָיוּתוֹ, כַּחֲמֵשׁ סְלָעִים שֶׁל בֵּן, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אֵין חַיָּיבִין בְּאַחְרָיוּתוֹ, כְּפִדְיוֹן מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי.
human_translation: one who designates redemption of a firstborn donkey and dies, Rabbi Eliezer says: bears responsibility like five sela of son, And the Rabbis say: does not bear responsibility. like redemption of second-tithe
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who separates the redemption of a firstborn donkey and it dies, Rabbi Eliezer says: They are obligated in its replacement, like five sela of a son. And the Sages say: They are not obligated in its replacement, like the redemption of a second tithe.

hebrew_text: הֵעִיד רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ וְרַבִּי צָדוֹק עַל פִּדְיוֹן פֶּטֶר חֲמוֹר שֶׁמֵּת, שֶׁאֵין כָּאן לַכֹּהֵן כְּלוּם. מֵת פֶּטֶר חֲמוֹר, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: יִקָּבֵר, וּמוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָתוֹ שֶׁל טָלֶה. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אֵין צָרִיךְ לְהִקָּבֵר, וְטָלֶה לַכֹּהֵן.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua and Rabbi Tzadok testified about redemption of a firstborn donkey that died, that the priest has nothing here, the firstborn donkey died, Rabbi Eliezer says: must be buried, and permitted to benefit from the lamb. And the Rabbis say: does not need to be buried, and the lamb to the priest.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehoshua and Rabbi Tzadok testified regarding the redemption of a firstborn donkey that died, that there is nothing here for the priest. If a firstborn donkey dies, Rabbi Eliezer says: it should be buried, and its meat is permitted for the consumption of a lamb. But the sages say: there is no need to bury it, and the lamb belongs to the priest.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר? דִּכְתִיב: ״אַךְ פָּדֹה תִפְדֶּה וְגוֹ׳״, מָה בְּכוֹר אָדָם חַיָּיב בְּאַחְרָיוּתוֹ, אַף בְּכוֹר בְּהֵמָה טְמֵאָה חַיָּיב בְּאַחְרָיוּתוֹ.
human_translation: Rav Yosef says: What is the reason of Rabbi Eliezer, As it is written: “Yet you shall redeem just as firstborn son, bears responsibility so too, a firstborn non-kosher animal, bears responsibility of their
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara said, Rav Yosef: What is the reason of Rabbi Eliezer? As it is written: "But the firstborn of man you shall redeem, and so on," just as the firstborn of a person is obligated in its redemption, so too the firstborn of an unclean animal is obligated in its redemption.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: אִי מָה בְּכוֹר אָדָם מוּתָּר בַּהֲנָאָה, אַף בְּכוֹר בְּהֵמָה טְמֵאָה מוּתָּר! וְכִי תֵּימָא הָכִי נָמֵי, וְהָתְנַן: מֵת פֶּטֶר חֲמוֹר, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: יִקָּבֵר. מַאי יִקָּבֵר? לָאו דְּאָסוּר בַּהֲנָאָה?
human_translation: Abaye said to him: If just as benefit firstborn son is permitted so too, the firstborn of a non-kosher animal permitted And if you would say indeed But didn’t we learn the firstborn donkey died, Rabbi Eliezer says: It must be buried? what it must be buried? not because benefit is prohibited?
llm_translation: He said to him, Abaye: If the firstborn of a person is permitted in benefit, so too the firstborn of an unclean animal is permitted! And if you will say so, then what about this case, as we have learned: "The firstborn of a donkey shall be redeemed," Rabbi Eliezer says: It shall be buried. What does it mean, "it shall be buried"? Is it not that it is not prohibited in benefit?

hebrew_text: לָא, יִקָּבֵר כִּבְכוֹר אָדָם. אֶלָּא, אָדָם בְּכוֹר הוּא דְּבָעֵי קְבוּרָה, פָּשׁוּט לָא בָּעֵי קְבוּרָה?
human_translation: No, it must be buried like firstborn son. But a person require burial is a firstborn an ordinary does not require burial?
llm_translation: Not, will be buried firstborn man. Rather, man firstborn he requires burial, simple not requires burial?

hebrew_text: וְעוֹד תַּנְיָא: מוֹדֶה רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ סְפֵק פֶּטֶר חֲמוֹר בְּתוֹךְ בֵּיתוֹ — שֶׁמַּפְרִישׁ טָלֶה עָלָיו, וְהוּא שֶׁלּוֹ!
human_translation: And furthermore, it is taught Rabbi Eliezer concedes with regard to an Israelite who has a donkey in his house a firstborn uncertain, that he designates a lamb for it and is his.
llm_translation: And furthermore it was taught: Rabbi Eliezer concedes regarding a Jew that if he has a doubt about the exemption of a donkey in his house - that he separates a lamb for it, and it belongs to him!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: אָמַר קְרָא ״אַךְ פָּדֹה תִפְדֶּה״, לִפְדִיָּיה הִקַּשְׁיתִּיו, וְלֹא לְדָבָר אַחֵר.
human_translation: Rather, Rava says the verse states: “Yet you shall redeem [ pado tifde ] I have compared it with regard to redemption, but not with regard to another matter.
llm_translation: Rather, Rava said: The verse states, "But you shall surely redeem," I have expounded upon its redemption, and not for any other matter.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן הָתָם: הָעֲרָכִין — בִּשְׁעָתָן, וּפִדְיוֹן הַבֵּן — אַחַר שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם, פִּדְיוֹן פֶּטֶר חֲמוֹר — לְאַלְתַּר.
human_translation: We learned elsewhere: Valuations on the time of And redeeming son, after thirty days redeeming a firstborn donkey, immediately.
llm_translation: We learned there: The evaluation - at their time, and the redemption of the son - after thirty days, the redemption of the firstborn donkey - immediately.

hebrew_text: וּפִדְיוֹן פֶּטֶר חֲמוֹר לְאַלְתַּר? וּרְמִינְהִי: אֵין בַּעֲרָכִין, וּבְפִדְיוֹן הַבֵּן, וּבִנְזִירוּת, וּבְפֶטֶר חֲמוֹר — פָּחוֹת מִשְּׁלֹשִׁים.
human_translation: And redeeming a firstborn donkey immediately? But raise a contradiction of valuations, and of redemption of son, and of nazirite vows, and of a firstborn donkey, do not less than thirty
llm_translation: Redemption of a firstborn donkey immediately? And it was asked: Are there no appraisals, and in the redemption of a son, and in the case of a Nazirite, and in the redemption of a donkey — less than thirty.

hebrew_text: וּמוֹסִיפִין עַד עוֹלָם!
human_translation: But one may add forever.
llm_translation: And we continue forever!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: לוֹמַר שֶׁאִם פְּדָאוֹ — פָּדוּי, מִכְּלָל דִּבְנוֹ אִם פְּדָאוֹ אֵינוֹ פָּדוּי? וְהָאִיתְּמַר: הַפּוֹדֶה אֶת בְּנוֹ בְּתוֹךְ שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם, רַב אָמַר: בְּנוֹ פָּדוּי!
human_translation: Rav Naḥman says: to say that if one redeemed it it is redeemed, By inference, of son, if one redeemed him is he not redeemed? But wasn’t it stated: one who redeems his son within thirty days Rav says: His son is redeemed?
llm_translation: Rav Nachman said: To say that if he redeemed - he is redeemed, from the inference that if he redeemed him he is not redeemed? And it was stated: One who redeems his son within thirty days, Rav said: His son is redeemed!

hebrew_text: לָאו אִיתְּמַר עֲלַהּ, אָמַר רָבָא: דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא ״מֵעַכְשָׁיו״ — אֵין בְּנוֹ פָּדוּי.
human_translation: Wasn’t it stated with regard to that Rava says: Everyone from now, his son is not redeemed.
llm_translation: It was not stated regarding it, Rava said: In the eyes of the entire world "from now" - he is not redeemed.

hebrew_text: רַב שֵׁשֶׁת אָמַר: לוֹמַר שֶׁאֵינוֹ עוֹבֵר עָלָיו.
human_translation: Rav Sheshet says: to say that one does not transgress
llm_translation: Rav Sheshet said: to say that he does not transgress upon it.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא: מִצְוָתוֹ כׇּל שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם, מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ — אוֹ פּוֹדֵהוּ אוֹ עוֹרְפוֹ. מַאי לָאו מִצְוָה לְשַׁהוֹתוֹ כׇּל שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם? לָא, מִצְוָה לִפְדּוֹתוֹ כׇּל שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם.
human_translation: Rami bar Ḥama raises an objection The mitzva of throughout thirty days from that forward he must either redeem it or break its neck. What, not a mitzva to wait it all thirty days No, a mitzva to redeem it throughout thirty days,
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: Ramei bar Ḥama raises a contradiction: His obligation is for thirty days, from here onward — either redeem him or break his neck. What, is it not a mitzvah to leave him for thirty days? No, it is a mitzvah to redeem him within thirty days.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, ״מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ אוֹ פּוֹדֵהוּ אוֹ עוֹבֵר עָלָיו״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ! אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: לָא קַשְׁיָא, הָא רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר דְּמַקֵּשׁי, הָא רַבָּנַן דְּלָא מַקְּשִׁי.
human_translation: If so, should have From that forward, either he redeems it or he transgresses Rather, Rava says: not difficult, this Rabbi Eliezer, who compares That the Rabbis, who do not compare
llm_translation: So it is, "From here and onwards, either redeem it or pass over it," what is the question? Rather, Rava said: It is not difficult, this is in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer who holds it difficult, while the Rabbis who do not hold it difficult.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ לֹא רָצָה לִפְדּוֹתוֹ — עוֹרְפוֹ מֵאֲחוֹרָיו וְקוֹבְרוֹ. מִצְוַת הַפְּדִיָּיה קוֹדֶמֶת לְמִצְוַת עֲרִיפָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אִם לֹא תִפְדֶּה וַעֲרַפְתּוֹ״.
human_translation: one did not wish to redeem he breaks its neck from behind and buries it. The mitzva of redeeming takes precedence over the mitzva of breaking the neck, as it is stated: “If you will not redeem it, then you shall break its neck”
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "If he does not wish to redeem him - he turns his back to him and buries him. The obligation of redemption takes precedence over the obligation of strangulation, as it is stated: 'If you do not redeem him, then you shall break his neck.'"

hebrew_text: מִצְוַת יְעִידָה קוֹדֶמֶת לְמִצְוַת הַפְּדִיָּיה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אֲשֶׁר לֹא יְעָדָהּ וְהֶפְדָּהּ״.
human_translation: The mitzva of designating takes precedence over the mitzva of redeeming as it is stated: who has not betrothed her to himself, then he shall let her be redeemed”
llm_translation: Command of testimony precedes command of redemption, as it is stated: "That which he did not designate and redeem."

hebrew_text: מִצְוַת הַיִּיבּוּם קוֹדֶמֶת לְמִצְוַת חֲלִיצָה, בָּרִאשׁוֹנָה שֶׁהָיוּ מִתְכַּוְּונִין לְשֵׁם מִצְוָה, וְעַכְשָׁיו שֶׁאֵין מִתְכַּוְּונִין לְשֵׁם מִצְוָה, אָמְרוּ: מִצְוַת חֲלִיצָה קוֹדֶמֶת לְמִצְוַת יִבּוּם.
human_translation: The mitzva of levirate marriage takes precedence over the mitzva of ḥalitza , initially, when would intend for the sake of the mitzva. But now that they do not intend for the sake of the mitzva, said the mitzva of ḥalitza takes precedence over the mitzva of levirate marriage.
llm_translation: The commandment of yibum takes precedence over the commandment of chalitzah, initially when they intended for the sake of the commandment, and now that they do not intend for the sake of the commandment, they said: the commandment of chalitzah takes precedence over the commandment of yibum.

hebrew_text: מִצְוַת הַגְּאוּלָּה בָּאָדוֹן, הוּא קוֹדֵם לְכׇל אָדָם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְאִם לֹא יִגָּאֵל וְנִמְכַּר בְּעֶרְכֶּךָ״.
human_translation: the mitzva of redemption by the owner takes precedence over any person, as it is stated: and if it is not redeemed, it shall be sold according to your valuation”
llm_translation: The commandment of redemption by the master, it precedes all people, as it is stated: "But if he is not redeemed by these means, then he shall be sold according to your valuation."

hebrew_text: הֲדַרַן עֲלָךְ הַלּוֹקֵחַ עוּבַּר חֲמוֹרוֹ.
llm_translation: The one who acquires the donkey, his burden is upon you.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הַלּוֹקֵחַ עוּבַּר פָּרָתוֹ שֶׁל נׇכְרִי, וְהַמּוֹכֵר לוֹ, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵינוֹ רַשַּׁאי, וְהַמִּשְׁתַּתֵּף לוֹ, וְהַמְקַבֵּל מִמֶּנּוּ, וְהַנּוֹתֵן לוֹ בְּקַבָּלָה — פָּטוּר מִן הַבְּכוֹרָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל״, אֲבָל לֹא בַּאֲחֵרִים.
human_translation: one who purchases the fetus of a cow belongs to a gentile; one who sells to even though one is not permitted one who enters into a partnership with one who receives from and one who gives in receivership, exempt from the firstborn as it is stated: in Israel, but not upon others.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who acquires the fetus of a non-Jew's cow, and then sells it to him, even though he is not permitted to do so, and the non-Jew participates with him, and he receives payment from him, and the non-Jew gives it to him as a gift — he is exempt from the laws of the firstborn, as it is stated "in Israel," but not in others.

hebrew_text: הַכֹּהֲנִים וְהַלְוִיִּם חַיָּיבִים, שֶׁלֹּא נִפְטְרוּ מִבְּכוֹר בְּהֵמָה טְהוֹרָה, אֶלָּא מִפִּדְיוֹן הַבֵּן וּמִפֶּטֶר חֲמוֹר.
human_translation: The priests and the Levites are obligated as they were not exempted from firstborn of a kosher animal; rather, from redemption of the son and from the firstborn donkey.
llm_translation: The priests and Levites are obligated, as they were not exempt from the firstborn of a clean animal, but rather from the redemption of the son and from the firstborn of a donkey.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַאי אִירְיָא דְּתָנֵי עוּבַּר חֲמוֹרוֹ בְּרֵישָׁא, וַהֲדַר תָּנֵי עוּבַּר פָּרָתוֹ? לִיתְנֵי בְּרֵישָׁא עוּבַּר פָּרָתוֹ, דִּקְדוּשַּׁת הַגּוּף הוּא, וַהֲדַר לִיתְנֵי עוּבַּר חֲמוֹרוֹ, דִּקְדוּשַּׁת דָּמִים הוּא.
human_translation: Why does specifically teach the fetus of his donkey first, and then teach the fetus of his cow? Let him first teach the fetus of his cow, as it is inherent sanctity, and let him then teach the fetus of his donkey, as it is sanctity value.
llm_translation: Gemara: What is the meaning of the teaching that one first designates the fetus of his donkey, and then designates the fetus of his cow? It should teach that one first designates the fetus of his cow, for it is the sanctity of the body, and then he designates the fetus of his donkey, for it is the sanctity of blood.

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי בְּמַעְרְבָא: אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא, אַיְּידֵי דַּחֲבִיבָא לֵיהּ, כִּדְרַבִּי חֲנִינָא, וְאִי בָּעֵית אֵימָא, אַיְּידֵי דְּזוּטְרָן מִילֵּיהּ דִּבְהֵמָה טְמֵאָה, פָּסֵיק וְשָׁדֵי לַהּ.
human_translation: They said in the West, If you wish, say since dear to in accordance with Rabbi Ḥanina And if you wish, say since the matters a non-kosher animal are few, completes and sets it
llm_translation: They said in the West: If you want, say that it is because he loves him, as Rabbi Chanina, and if you want, say that it is because he cuts off the tail of a ritually impure animal, he should be stopped and silenced.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק בַּר נַחְמָנִי אָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אוֹשַׁעְיָא: יִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁנָּתַן מָעוֹת לְגוֹי בִּבְהֶמְתּוֹ בְּדִינֵיהֶם, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא מָשַׁךְ — קָנָה, וְחַיֶּיבֶת בִּבְכוֹרָה. וְגוֹי שֶׁנָּתַן מָעוֹת לְיִשְׂרָאֵל בִּבְהֶמְתּוֹ בְּדִינֵיהֶם, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא מָשַׁךְ — קָנָה, וּפָטוּר מִן הַבְּכוֹרָה.
human_translation: Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Naḥmani says Reish Lakish said in the name of Rabbi Oshaya: a Jew who gave money to a gentile to animal according to their laws, even though did not pull he has acquired and is obligated firstborn And a gentile who gave money to a Jew to animal according to their laws, even though did not pull he has acquired and is exempt from firstborn
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Yitzchak bar Nachmani said Reish Lakish in the name of Rabbi Oshaya: If a Jew gave money to a non-Jew for his animal in their courts, even though he did not pull it, he acquired it, and it is obligated in firstborn status. And if a non-Jew gave money to a Jew for his animal in their courts, even though he did not pull it, he acquired it, and it is exempt from firstborn status.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: יִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁנָּתַן מָעוֹת לְגוֹי בְּדִינֵיהֶם, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא מָשַׁךְ — קָנָה וְחַיֶּיבֶת בִּבְכוֹרָה.
human_translation: The Master said: a Jew who gave money to a gentile according to their laws, even though he did not pull he has acquired and is obligated firstborn
llm_translation: Master said: If an Israelite gave money to a gentile in their legal matters, even though he did not pull him into court — he acquires the right to the money and is obligated in the laws of the firstborn.

hebrew_text: מַאי ״בְּדִינֵיהֶם״? אִי נֵימָא בְּדִינֵיהֶם דְּגוּפֵיהּ, דְּאָתֵי בְּקַל וָחוֹמֶר: אִם גּוּפֵיהּ קָנֵי לֵיהּ יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּכֶסֶף, דִּכְתִיב ״לָרֶשֶׁת אֲחוּזָּה״,
human_translation: What According to their laws? If we say to the laws to person is derived by a fortiori If person is acquired by a Jew through money, as it is written: to hold for an ancestral possession”
llm_translation: What is "with their judgments"? If you say with their own judgments, that comes with a fortiori reasoning: if he acquires it with his own body, Israel acquires it with money, as it is written, "to inherit property."

hebrew_text: הִקִּישׁוֹ הַכָּתוּב לַאֲחוּזָּה, מָה אֲחוּזָּה נִקְנֵית בְּכֶסֶף וּבִשְׁטָר וּבַחֲזָקָה, אַף עֶבֶד כְּנַעֲנִי נִקְנֶה בְּכֶסֶף. מָמוֹנוֹ — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן הוּא?
human_translation: The verse compares to an ancestral possession, Just as an ancestral possession is acquired by of money, or with a bill of sale, or through taking possession, so too, a Canaanite slave is acquired by money. is it not all the more so property
llm_translation: The verse compared it to land, what land is acquired with money, contract, and possession, so too a Canaanite slave is acquired with money. His money - is it not all the more so?

hebrew_text: אִם כֵּן, אֲפִילּוּ בִּשְׁטָר וּבַחֲזָקָה נָמֵי! וְעוֹד, יִשְׂרָאֵל מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל יוֹכִיחַו, דְּגוּפֵיהּ קָנֵי לֵיהּ בְּכֶסֶף, מָמוֹנוֹ בִּמְשִׁיכָה!
human_translation: If so, even with a bill of sale or by taking possession, And furthermore, a Jew from a Jew proves as he acquires person with money his property by pulling.
llm_translation: If so, even with a document and with possession, yes! And furthermore, let Israel from Israel prove, that his body he acquired with money, his wealth with drawing out!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: בְּדִינֵיהֶם שֶׁפָּסְקָה לָהֶם תּוֹרָה, ״אוֹ קָנֹה מִיַּד עֲמִיתֶךָ״ — מִיַּד עֲמִיתֶךָ הוּא דְּבִמְשִׁיכָה, הָא מִיַּד גּוֹי בְּכֶסֶף.
human_translation: Rather, Abaye says their laws that the Torah prescribed for their “Or buy of your counterpart’s hand” it is from the hand of your counterpart, that is by pulling. from the hand of a gentile through money.
llm_translation: Rather, Abaye said: In their laws, when the Torah has already been divided for them, "or acquires from the hand of his fellow" — from the hand of his fellow is referring to a purchase, whereas from the hand of a gentile is with money.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא: מִיַּד גּוֹי — כְּלָל כְּלָל לָא! אָמְרִי: לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, קַל וָחוֹמֶר הוּא — אִם גּוּפוֹ קוֹנֶה, מָמוֹנוֹ לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?
human_translation: But say cannot at all from the hand of a gentile. said cannot enter your mind, is an a fortiori If purchase person not all the more so property?
llm_translation: And why? From the hand of a non-Jew - absolutely not! They said: Your opinion did not come out, it is a fortiori - if his body acquires, certainly not his money?

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא: מִיַּד גּוֹי — עַד דְּאִיכָּא תַּרְתֵּי! אָמְרִי: וְלָאו קַל וָחוֹמֶר הוּא? גּוּפוֹ בְּאַחַת, מָמוֹנוֹ בִּשְׁתַּיִם?! וְאֵימָא: אוֹ בְּהָא אוֹ בְּהָא, דּוּמְיָא דַּ״עֲמִיתֶךָ״.
human_translation: But say from the hand of a gentile until two said Isn’t it an a fortiori his person through one his property through two But say either this or that similar to your counterpart:
llm_translation: And why not? From the hand of a non-Jew—until there are two! They said: Is it not a fortiori? His body in one, his money in two?! And why not? Either in this or in that, similar to "your fellow."

hebrew_text: מָה ״עֲמִיתֶךָ״ בַּחֲדָא, אַף גּוֹי נָמֵי בַּחֲדָא.
human_translation: Just as your counterpart with one so too, a gentile, also with one with money.
llm_translation: "What 'your fellow' in one, also a gentile in one."

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: וְגוֹי שֶׁנָּתַן מָעוֹת לְיִשְׂרָאֵל בִּבְהֶמְתּוֹ בְּדִינֵיהֶן, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא מָשַׁךְ — קָנָה, וּפָטוּר מִן הַבְּכוֹרָה. מַאי בְּדִינֵיהֶן? אִילֵּימָא בְּדִינֵיהֶן דְּגוּפֵיהּ, מִשּׁוּם דְּאָתֵי בְּקַל וָחוֹמֶר: אִם גּוּפוֹ יִשְׂרָאֵל קָנֵי לֵיהּ בְּכֶסֶף, דִּכְתִיב ״מִכֶּסֶף מִקְנָתוֹ״, מָמוֹנוֹ לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?
human_translation: The Master said: And a gentile who gave money to a Jew to animal according to their laws, even though did not pull he has acquired and is exempt from firstborn The Gemara clarifies: What is according to their laws? If we say According to their laws of the person as it may be derived an a fortiori If acquires the body of a Jew with money, as it is written “From the money of his purchase” property not all the more so
llm_translation: Master said: And a gentile who gave money to a Jew for his animal in their laws, even though he did not pull it – he acquires it, and he is exempt from the firstborn. What are their laws? If you will say their laws of its body, because it comes with a logical inference: if his body, an Israelite acquires it with money, as it is written "from the money of his purchase," his money certainly so?

hebrew_text: יִשְׂרָאֵל מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל יוֹכִיחַו, דְּגוּפוֹ קָנֵי בְּכֶסֶף, מָמוֹנוֹ בִּמְשִׁיכָה! אֶלָּא אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: בְּדִינֵיהֶם שֶׁפָּסְקָה לָהֶם תּוֹרָה, ״וְכִי תִמְכְּרוּ מִמְכָּר לַעֲמִיתֶךָ״ — לַעֲמִיתֶךָ בִּמְשִׁיכָה, הָא לְגוֹי בְּכֶסֶף.
human_translation: a Jew from a Jew will prove person one acquires with money, while the property by pulling. Rather, Abaye said: according to their laws, that the Torah prescribed “And if you sell a sale item to your counterpart” To your counterpart, is by pulling, from the hand of a gentile with money.
llm_translation: Israel from Israel will they argue, that his body acquires with silver, his money with pulling! Rather said Abbaye: in their laws that Torah has decreed for them, "And if you sell anything to your fellow or buy from your fellow" — to your fellow with pulling, but to a non-Jew with silver.

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא: לְגוֹי כְּלָל כְּלָל לָא! אָמְרִי: לָאו קַל וָחוֹמֶר הוּא? אִם גּוּפוֹ קָנָה, מָמוֹנוֹ לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?
human_translation: But say To a gentile, not at all, said But isn’t it an a fortiori If purchase person not all the more so property?
llm_translation: And why? For a non-Jew, in general, in general, no! They said: Is it not a fortiori? If his body acquired property, his money certainly acquired property?

hebrew_text: אֵימָא: לְגוֹי עַד דְּאִיכָּא תַּרְתֵּי! לָאו קַל וָחוֹמֶר הוּא? גּוּפוֹ בְּאֶחָד, מָמוֹנוֹ בִּשְׁתַּיִם?!
human_translation: Say but to a gentile until two said But isn’t it an a fortiori person with one his property with two
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima: l'goy ad d'eikka tartei! Lavo kal va'chomer hu? Gufo b'echad, mamono b'shtayim?!" English translation: "Say: to a non-Jew until when two! Is it not a fortiori? His body in one, his money in two?!"

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא: אוֹ בְּהָא אוֹ בְּהָא, דּוּמְיָא דַּ״עֲמִיתֶךָ״;
human_translation: But say either with this or with that paying similar to your counterpart,
llm_translation: And why not: either in this or in that, similar to "your fellow."

hebrew_text: מָה ״עֲמִיתֶךָ״ בְּאַחַת, אַף גּוֹי נָמֵי בְּאַחַת.
human_translation: Just as your counterpart through one so too, a gentile through one
llm_translation: "What 'your fellow' in one, also a gentile likewise in one."

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: וּלְאָמֵימָר דְּאָמַר מְשִׁיכָה בְּגוֹי קוֹנָה, הָנִיחָא אִי סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן דְּאָמַר: דְּבַר תּוֹרָה מָעוֹת קוֹנוֹת, מְשִׁיכָה לֹא, אַהֲנִי ״לַעֲמִיתֶךָ״ — לַעֲמִיתֶךָ בְּכֶסֶף, לְגוֹי בִּמְשִׁיכָה.
human_translation: said: And according to Ameimar, who says pulling effects acquisition in a gentile, this works out well if he holds in accordance with Rabbi Yoḥanan, who says: By Torah law, money effects acquisition, pulling not. “of your counterpart” with your counterpart, through money, with a gentile by pulling.
llm_translation: They said: And regarding Amemar who said, "Acquisition through pulling in a non-Jew is valid," let it be. If he holds like Rabbi Yochanan who said: "Money acquires a Torah item, but pulling does not," then the verse "to your fellow" applies to your fellow with money, to a non-Jew with pulling.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אִי סָבַר לַהּ כְּרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ, דְּאָמַר: מְשִׁיכָה מְפוֹרֶשֶׁת מִן הַתּוֹרָה, לַעֲמִיתֶךָ בִּמְשִׁיכָה, וּלְגוֹי בִּמְשִׁיכָה, ״לַעֲמִיתֶךָ״ לְמָה לִי?
human_translation: But if holds in accordance with Reish Lakish, who says: pulling is explicit in the Torah, with your counterpart by pulling, and with a gentile by pulling. why do I “of your counterpart”?
llm_translation: Rather, if he holds like Reish Lakish, for he said: "Explicit drawing from the Torah, to your fellow with drawing, and to a non-Jew with drawing, 'to your fellow' - why do I need it?"

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: לַעֲמִיתֶךָ אַתָּה מַחְזִיר אוֹנָאָה, וְאִי אַתָּה מַחֲזִיר אוֹנָאָה לְגוֹי. לְגוֹי — מֵ״אַל תּוֹנוּ אִישׁ אֶת אָחִיו״ נָפְקָא!
human_translation: said You return exploitation to your counterpart, but you do not return exploitation to a gentile. to a gentile is derived from “A man shall not exploit his brother.”
llm_translation: They said: "To your fellow you shall return ona'ah, but if you do not return ona'ah to a gentile. To a gentile - from 'Do not wrong one another' it is derived!"

hebrew_text: חַד בְּגוֹי, וְחַד בְּהֶקְדֵּשׁ, וּצְרִיכִי, דְּאִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא חַד — הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: לְגוֹי הוּא דְּאֵין לוֹ אוֹנָאָה, אֲבָל הֶקְדֵּשׁ — יֵשׁ לוֹ אוֹנָאָה, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: One to a gentile, and one to consecrated And are necessary, as, had the Merciful One written one I would say: It is with a gentile that one is not exploitation; but consecrated one is exploitation. teaches us
llm_translation: One in a non-Jew, and one in a consecrated item, and it is necessary, for if the Merciful One wrote one — I would say: It is a non-Jew who does not have ona'ah, but a consecrated item — it has ona'ah, this is what he is teaching us.

hebrew_text: הָנִיחָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר גְּזֵילוֹ אָסוּר — הַיְינוּ דְּאִצְטְרִיךְ קְרָא לְמִישְׁרֵי אוֹנָאָה, אֶלָּא אִי סָבַר לַהּ כְּמַאן דְּאָמַר גְּזֵילוֹ שֶׁל גּוֹי מוּתָּר, אוֹנָאָה מִיבַּעְיָא? אָמְרִי: אִי סָבַר לַהּ כְּמַאן דְּאָמַר גְּזֵילוֹ מוּתָּר — עַל כּוּרְחָיךְ כְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן סְבִירָא לֵיהּ.
human_translation: This works out well according to the one who says his robbery, prohibited, this is that a verse is necessary to permit exploitation But if holds in accordance with the one who says his robbery is permitted, is it necessary exploitation said: If holds in accordance with the one who says his robbery is permitted, perforce he holds in accordance with Rabbi
llm_translation: He left it for the one who says that robbery is prohibited - that is, that a verse is necessary for the rectification of oppression. But if he holds like the one who says that the robbery of a non-Jew is permitted, is oppression necessary? They said: If he holds like the one who says that his robbery is permitted - according to Rabbi Yochanan, he is likely to hold that way.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: הַלּוֹקֵחַ גְּרוּטָאוֹת מִן הַגּוֹיִם, וּמָצָא בָּהֶן עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה — אִם עַד שֶׁלֹּא נָתַן מָעוֹת מָשַׁךְ — יַחֲזִיר, וְאִם מִשֶּׁנָּתַן מָעוֹת מָשַׁךְ — יוֹלִיךְ הֲנָאָה לְיָם הַמֶּלַח.
human_translation: raises an objection one who buys broken vessels [ gerutaot ] from the gentiles and finds among them idol worship, if he pulled before he gave money he may return if he pulled after he gave money take into the Dead Sea.
llm_translation: Challenger: One who takes dried figs from the Gentiles, and found in them idol worship - if he did not give money, he should return them, but if he gave money, he should throw them into the Dead Sea.

hebrew_text: וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ מָעוֹת קוֹנוֹת, מְשִׁיכָה לְמָה לִּי? הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — שֶׁקִּיבֵּל עָלָיו לָדוּן בְּדִינֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל. אִי הָכִי, מָעוֹת לְמָה לִי? הָכִי קָאָמַר: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁנָּתַן מָעוֹת, אִי מָשֵׁיךְ — אִין, וְאִי לָא — לָא.
human_translation: And if you say money acquires why do I pulling Here we are dealing with where accepted upon himself to adjudicated by Jewish law. If so, why do I money this is what means: Even though gave money If he pulled yes, and if not, not
llm_translation: If you say "money acquires," why do I need a pull? Here, what are we dealing with? - That he accepted upon himself to judge in the laws of Israel. If so, why do I need money? This is what he is saying: Even though money was given, if he does not pull - no, and if he does - yes.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, קַשְׁיָא רֵישָׁא! אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: רֵישָׁא מִשּׁוּם דְּאִיכָּא מִקָּח טָעוּת. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: רֵישָׁא מִשּׁוּם דְּאִיכָּא מִקָּח טָעוּת, סֵיפָא לֵיכָּא מִקָּח טָעוּת?
human_translation: If so, the first clause difficult, Abaye said the first clause because there is a mistaken transaction, Rava said to the first clause because there is a mistaken transaction. the latter clause there is no mistaken transaction?
llm_translation: So it is difficult, the beginning! Abaye said: The beginning because there is a mistaken acquisition. Rava said to him: The beginning because there is a mistaken acquisition, is there not a mistaken acquisition in the end?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: רֵישָׁא וְסֵיפָא מִקָּח טָעוּת, רֵישָׁא דְּלָא יָהֵיב זוּזֵי — לָא מִיחְזֵי כַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה בְּיַד יִשְׂרָאֵל, סֵיפָא דְּיָהֵיב זוּזֵי — מִיחְזֵי כַּעֲבוֹדָה זָרָה בְּיַד יִשְׂרָאֵל.
human_translation: Rather, Rava said: the first clause and the latter clause a mistaken transaction, but the first clause, where did not pay dinars, it does not appear as idol worship in the possession of a Jew, the latter clause, where did pay him the dinars, it appears as idol worship in the possession of a Jew,
llm_translation: Rather, Rava said: The beginning and the end of a transaction are erroneous. The beginning, where he did not give the money - it does not appear like foreign worship in the hands of Israel. The end, where he did give the money - it appears like foreign worship in the hands of Israel.

hebrew_text: וְאַבַּיֵּי אָמַר לָךְ: רֵישָׁא מִקָּח טָעוּת, דְּלָא יָדַע, דְּהָא לָא יְהַיב לֵיהּ זוּזֵי. סֵיפָא לָאו מִקָּח טָעוּת הוּא, דְּכֵיוָן דִּיהַיב זוּזֵי, כִּי קָא מָשֵׁיךְ — אִיבְּעִי לְעַיּוֹנֵי וַהֲדַר מִימְשָׁךְ.
human_translation: And Abaye said to you: The first clause a mistaken transaction, as he did not know as he did not give him the dinars the latter clause is not a mistaken transaction, as since he gave the dinars when he pull it, he should have inspected and then pulled it.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And Abbaye said to you: The beginning is a mistaken acquisition, for he did not know, since he did not give him the money. The end is not a mistaken acquisition, for since he gave him the money, when he pulls back — if he wants to reconsider, he may retract.

hebrew_text: רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: מִדְּרֵישָׁא מְשִׁיכָה אֵינָהּ קוֹנָה, סֵיפָא נָמֵי מְשִׁיכָה אֵינָהּ קוֹנָה, וְאַיְּידֵי דִּתְנָא רֵישָׁא ״מָשַׁךְ״, תְּנָא סֵיפָא נָמֵי ״מָשַׁךְ״.
human_translation: Rav Ashi says: from the first clause, pulling does not effect acquisition, the latter clause too, pulling does not effect acquisition. But since the first clause taught Pulled, the latter clause also taught Pulled,
llm_translation: Rav Ashi said: From the beginning of the teaching, pulling does not acquire. The end also, pulling does not acquire. And since the first part taught "pulled," the end part also taught "pulled."

hebrew_text: רָבִינָא אָמַר: מִדְּסֵיפָא מְשִׁיכָה קוֹנָה, רֵישָׁא נָמֵי מְשִׁיכָה קוֹנָה, וְרֵישָׁא הָכִי קָאָמַר: אִם לֹא נָתַן וְלֹא מָשַׁךְ — יַחְזוֹר. מַאי יַחְזוֹר? יַחְזוֹר בִּדְבָרִים.
human_translation: Ravina said: From the latter clause, pulling effects acquisition, the first clause too, pulling effects acquisition. And the first clause, this is saying: If did not give and did not pull he returns What Returns, returns, on verbal
llm_translation: Ravinah said: From the end, acquisition; from the beginning, acquisition. And thus the beginning is saying: If he did not give and did not draw out - he should return. What does it mean "he should return"? He should return with words.

hebrew_text: קָסָבַר: דְּבָרִים יֵשׁ בָּהֶם מִשּׁוּם מְחוּסְּרֵי אֲמָנָה, וְהָנֵי מִילֵּי — יִשְׂרָאֵל מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל, דְּקָיְימִי בְּדִבּוּרַיְיהוּ, אֲבָל יִשְׂרָאֵל מִגּוֹיִם, דְּאִינְהוּ לָא קָיְימִי בְּדִבּוּרַיְיהוּ — לָא.
human_translation: he holds: a verbal constitutes an act of bad faith And this statement a Jew from Jew, as they uphold their verbal But a Jew from gentiles, as they not to uphold their verbal not
llm_translation: He holds: there are matters that involve issues of trustworthiness, and these words - Israel from Israel, who are consistent in their speech, but Israel from the nations, who are not consistent in their speech - not.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ כׇּל הַקֳּדָשִׁים שֶׁקָּדַם מוּם קָבוּעַ לְהֶקְדֵּשָׁן וְנִפְדּוּ — חַיָּיבִין בַּבְּכוֹרָה וּבַמַּתָּנוֹת, וְיוֹצְאִין לְחוּלִּין לִיגָּזֵז וְלֵיעָבֵד, וְלָדָן וַחֲלָבָן מוּתָּר לְאַחַר פִּדְיוֹנָן.
human_translation: All sacrificial which a permanent blemish preceded their consecration and they were redeemed, are obligated in a firstborn, and in the gifts and they can emerge non-sacred to be shorn and to be utilized for labor. their offspring and their milk are permitted after their redemption.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: All consecrated items that had a permanent blemish before they were sanctified and were redeemed— are obligated in the laws of firstborn animals and in the laws of gifts to the priests, and they may be used for secular purposes, to shear them and to work them, and their offspring and milk are permitted after their redemption.

hebrew_text: וְהַשּׁוֹחֲטָן בַּחוּץ פָּטוּר, וְאֵין עוֹשִׂין תְּמוּרָה, וְאִם מֵתוּ — יִפָּדוּ, חוּץ מִן הַבְּכוֹר וּמִן הַמַּעֲשֵׂר.
human_translation: And one who slaughters them outside exempt and do not render a substitute And if died they may be redeemed except for the firstborn and the tithe.
llm_translation: The one slaughtering outside is exempt, and they do not make an exchange, and if they die - they should be redeemed, except for the firstborn and from the tithe.

hebrew_text: וְכׇל שֶׁקָּדַם הֶקְדֵּשָׁן אֶת מוּמָן, אוֹ מוּם עוֹבֵר לְהֶקְדֵּשָׁן, וּלְאַחַר מִכָּאן נוֹלַד לָהֶן מוּם קָבוּעַ לְהֶקְדֵּשָׁן וְנִפְדּוּ — פְּטוּרִין מִן הַבְּכוֹרָה וּמִן הַמַּתָּנוֹת, וְאֵינָן יוֹצְאִין לְחוּלִּין לִיגָּזֵז וְלֵיעָבֵד.
human_translation: And all whose consecration preceded their blemish, or a temporary blemish to their consecration and afterward developed a permanent blemish and they were redeemed, they are exempt from, a firstborn, and from the gifts and they do not emerge non-sacred to be shorn and to be utilized for labor.
llm_translation: And all that the consecrated one preceded its blemish, or a blemish passed to the consecrated one, and after this a blemish was born to them designated for the consecrated one and they were redeemed - they are exempt from the firstborn and from gifts, and they do not go out to secular use to be sheared and worked.

hebrew_text: וְלָדָן וַחֲלָבָן אָסוּר לְאַחַר פִּדְיוֹנָן, וְהַשּׁוֹחֲטָן בַּחוּץ חַיָּיב, וְעוֹשִׂין תְּמוּרָה, וְאִם מֵתוּ — יִקָּבֵרוּ.
human_translation: their offspring, and their milk, are prohibited after their redemption. And one who slaughters them outside liable and render a substitute And if died they must be buried.
llm_translation: Dan and Chalban are forbidden after their redemption, and one who slaughters them outside is liable, and they make a substitution, and if they die - they shall be buried.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ טַעְמָא דְּנִפְדּוּ, הָא לֹא נִפְדּוּ — פְּטוּרִין מִן הַבְּכוֹרָה וּמִן הַמַּתָּנוֹת. קָסָבַר: קְדוּשַּׁת דָּמִים מְדַחָה מִן הַבְּכוֹרָה וּמִן הַמַּתָּנוֹת.
human_translation: The reason that they were redeemed. But if they were not redeemed, they are exempt from a firstborn and from the gifts. holds: Sanctity value defers, from of the firstborn and from the gifts.
llm_translation: The taste of redemption, if they were not redeemed - exempt from the firstborn and from gifts. He holds: the sanctity of blood pushes aside from the firstborn and from gifts.

hebrew_text: וְיוֹצְאִין לְחוּלִּין וְכוּ׳. טַעְמָא דְּנִפְדּוּ, הָא לֹא נִפְדּוּ — אֲסִירִי בְּגִיזָּה וַעֲבוֹדָה. מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, דְּאָמַר: קׇדְשֵׁי בֶּדֶק הַבַּיִת אֲסוּרִין בְּגִיזָּה וַעֲבוֹדָה?
human_translation: And they can emerge non-sacred The reason that they were redeemed. But if they were not redeemed, are prohibited with regard to shearing and labor. This supports of Rabbi Eliezer, who says: consecrated for the Temple maintenance are prohibited with regard to shearing and labor.
llm_translation: They may go out to profane (activities) and so forth. The reason they were redeemed, if they were not redeemed - they are prohibited in shearing and labor. This supports Rabbi Eliezer, who said: The consecrated animals of the Temple courtyard are prohibited in shearing and labor?

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: לָא, קְדוּשַּׁת דָּמִים לַמִּזְבֵּחַ הוּא דְּמִיחַלְּפָא בִּקְדוּשַּׁת הַגּוּף לַמִּזְבֵּחַ, גְּזַרוּ בְּהוּ רַבָּנַן, אֲבָל קׇדְשֵׁי בֶּדֶק הַבַּיִת — לָא.
human_translation: said: No; it is sanctity value for the altar, which exchanged inherent sanctity for the altar, the Sages decreed with it, But consecrated for the Temple maintenance, no
llm_translation: They said: No, the sanctity of blood is for the altar, as it is exchanged with the sanctity of the body for the altar. The Rabbis decreed upon it, but the consecrated items of the Temple courtyard - no.

hebrew_text: וְלָדָן וַחֲלָבָן מוּתָּר כּוּ׳. הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵּימָא דְּאִיעַבַּר וְאִתְיְלִיד לְאַחַר פִּדְיוֹנָן — פְּשִׁיטָא, חוּלִּין נִינְהוּ! אֶלָּא דְּאִיעַבַּר לִפְנֵי פִּדְיוֹנָן, וְאִתְיְלִיד לְאַחַר פִּדְיוֹנָן.
human_translation: their offspring and their milk are permitted What are the circumstances If we say where became pregnant and gave birth after their redemption, obvious they are non-sacred Rather, where they became pregnant before their redemption, and gave birth after their redemption,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And Ladan and Chalban are permitted, as it is stated. How so? If you say that it was already formed and was born after their redemption - it is obvious, they are mundane! Rather, it was formed before their redemption, and was born after their redemption." English translation: "And Ladan and Chalban are permitted, as it is stated. How so? If you say that it was already formed and was born after their redemption - it is obvious, they are mundane! Rather, it was formed before their redemption, and was born after their redemption."

hebrew_text: הָא לִפְנֵי פִּדְיוֹנָן — אֲסִירִי.
human_translation: But before their redemption, are prohibited
llm_translation: This is before the Pidyonan - they are prisoners.

hebrew_text: נִפְדִּין תְּמִימִים אוֹ אֵין נִפְדִּין תְּמִימִין?
human_translation: are they redeemed unblemished, or are they not redeemed unblemished?
llm_translation: Redeemed are the innocent or not redeemed are the innocent?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הַמַּתְפִּיס בַּעֲלֵי מוּמִין קְבוּעִין לְגַבֵּי מִזְבֵּחַ, וְיָלְדוּ — יִמָּכְרוּ, וְאֵין צְרִיכִין מוּם, שֶׁאֵין קְדוּשָּׁה חָלָה עֲלֵיהֶן, שֶׁלֹּא יְהֵא טָפֵל חָמוּר מִן הָעִיקָּר.
human_translation: Come hear one who dedicates permanently blemished for the altar, and gave birth, may be sold and they do not require a blemish that they are not imbued with sanctity, that the subsidiary not be stringent than the primary
llm_translation: Come and hear: One who seizes blemished animals designated for the altar, and they give birth - they shall be sold, and there is no need for a blemish, because sanctity does not rest upon them, so that a secondary matter should not be more severe than the primary.

hebrew_text: טַעְמָא, שֶׁלֹּא יְהֵא טָפֵל חָמוּר מִן הָעִיקָּר, אֲבָל הִקְדִּישׁ זָכָר לְדָמָיו — קָדוֹשׁ קְדוּשַּׁת הַגּוּף. מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ לְרָבָא, דְּאָמַר רָבָא: הִקְדִּישׁ זָכָר לְדָמָיו — קָדוֹשׁ קְדוּשַּׁת הַגּוּף.
human_translation: The reason that the subsidiary not be stringent than the primary But one consecrated male for its value, it is sanctified with inherent sanctity. this supports of Rava, as Rava says: one consecrated a male for its value, it is sanctified with inherent sanctity.
llm_translation: Reason, that it should not be secondary more than the primary, but he sanctified a male to his value — holy holiness of the body. It supports for Rava, for Rava said: he sanctified a male to his value — holy holiness of the body.

hebrew_text: וְהַשּׁוֹחֲטָן בַּחוּץ פָּטוּר. רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר מַתְנֵי ״חַיָּיב״, וּמוֹקֵי לַהּ בְּבָמַת יָחִיד.
human_translation: And one who slaughters them outside exempt. Rabbi Elazar teaches liable, and he interprets referring to altar of an individual.
llm_translation: The one who slaughters outside is exempt. Rabbi Elazar teaches "liable," and exempts her on a private altar.

hebrew_text: דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: מִנַּיִן לַזּוֹבֵחַ בְּהֵמָה בַּעֲלַת מוּם בְּבָמַת יָחִיד בִּשְׁעַת הֶיתֵּר הַבָּמוֹת, שֶׁהוּא בְּלֹא תַעֲשֶׂה? שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לֹא תִזְבַּח לַה׳ אֱלֹהֶיךָ שׁוֹר וָשֶׂה״, אִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לְבָמָה גְּדוֹלָה, דִּכְתִיב: ״עַוֶּרֶת אוֹ שָׁבוּר וְגוֹ׳״, תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לְבָמַת יָחִיד.
human_translation: As Rabbi Elazar says: From where that one who slaughters a blemished animal upon altar of an individual at a time when altars are permitted is in a prohibition? as it is stated: “You shall not sacrifice to the Lord an ox, or a sheep, If is not to matter of a great altar, as it is written: “Blind or broken apply matter of altar of an individual.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Rabbi Elazar said: From where do we derive that one may slaughter a blemished animal for a private altar at the time when the public altars are permitted, which is a negative commandment? As it is stated: "You shall not sacrifice to the Lord your God an ox or a sheep" - if it is not relevant to a large altar, as it is written: "A blind one, or a broken one, etc.," allow it for a private altar.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא: אִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לְקָדָשִׁים — תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לִבְכוֹר, סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וְקָדוֹשׁ כְּשֶׁהוּא בַּעַל מוּם — לִיקְרַב נָמֵי כְּשֶׁהוּא בַּעַל מוּם, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּלָא!
human_translation: say If is not to matter of sacrificial apply it matter of a firstborn, enter your mind to say: Since is sanctified when it is blemished let it also be sacrificed when it is a blemished animal. teach us that not
llm_translation: Concerning what? If it is not relevant to holy things — give it relevance to the firstborn. Is it not your opinion that since it is blemished, it should be brought near like a blemished one, it is evident to us that it is not so!

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: בְּכוֹר בְּהֶדְיָא כְּתִיב בֵּיהּ ״פִּסֵּחַ אוֹ עִוֵּר לֹא תִזְבָּחֶנּוּ״.
human_translation: said a firstborn, written explicitly with regard to it: lameness, or blindness…you shall not sacrifice it”
llm_translation: They said: "Regarding a firstborn, it is written in it, 'You shall not sacrifice the Passover offering or a blind one.'"

hebrew_text: וְאֵימָא: אִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לְקָדָשִׁים — תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לְמַעֲשֵׂר, דְּסָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וְקָדוֹשׁ בְּמוּמוֹ, דִּכְתִיב: ״לֹא יְבַקֵּר בֵּין טוֹב לָרַע״, נִקְרַב נָמֵי בְּמוּמֵיהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּלָא!
human_translation: But say: If is not to matter of sacrificial apply it to matter of tithe, as enter your mind to say: Since sacred with its blemish, as it is written: “He shall not inquire whether it be good or bad” let it also be sacrificed with its blemish. teach us that not
llm_translation: And why? If it is not fit for holy things - designate it for tithe, for it is logical in your opinion: since it is holy with a blemish, as it is written: "He shall not distinguish between good and bad," let us bring it close with its blemishes, it is teaching us that it is not!

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: מַעֲשֵׂר נָמֵי גָּמַר ״הַעֲבָרָה״ ״הַעֲבָרָה״ מִבְּכוֹר.
human_translation: said tithe as well, derived from Passing, passing the firstborn
llm_translation: They said: tithe truly completes "the crossing" "the crossing" from firstborn.

hebrew_text: אֵימָא: תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לִתְמוּרַת קָדָשִׁים, דְּסָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וּקְדוֹשָׁה כְּשֶׁהִיא בַּעֲלַת מוּם, דִּכְתִיב: ״לֹא יַחֲלִיפֶנּוּ וְלֹא יָמִיר אוֹתוֹ וְגוֹ׳״, קָרֵיבָה נָמֵי כְּשֶׁהִיא בַּעֲלַת מוּם, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּלָא!
human_translation: say apply to matter of substituted for sacrificial as enter your mind to say: Since sacred when it is blemished, as it is written: “He shall not exchange it, nor substitute it, it may likewise be sacrificed when it is blemished. teach us that not
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima: T'nehu inyan litmura d'kadashim, d'salka da'atach ameina: Ho'il ukedusha k'shehi ba'alat mum, dikhtiv: 'Lo yachalifenu velo yamir oto vego,' kareivah namei k'shehi ba'alat mum, ka mashma lan d'la!" English translation: "Say: Give it as an exchange for consecrated items, since your mind has been made up: Since sanctity, when it is blemished, as it is written: 'He shall not exchange it nor substitute it,' it is also inferred when it is blemished, it is implied to us that it is not!"

hebrew_text: אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְהָיָה הוּא וּתְמוּרָתוֹ״, מַקִּישׁ תְּמוּרָתוֹ לוֹ — מָה הוּא בַּעַל מוּם לֹא, אַף תְּמוּרָתוֹ בַּעַל מוּם לֹא.
human_translation: the verse states: “It and that for which it is substituted compares a substitute to Just as not blemished, so too, its substitute not blemished.
llm_translation: The verse says: "And it shall be, he and his substitute," equating his substitute to him - just as he is not blemished, so too his substitute is not blemished.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַבִּי זֵירָא: אֵימָא, תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לְוַלְדוֹת קָדָשִׁים, דְּסָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וּקְדוֹשִׁין כְּשֶׁהֵן בַּעֲלֵי מוּמִין אַגַּב אִמָּן, כְּשֶׁהֵן בַּעֲלֵי מוּמִין נָמֵי קָרְבִי, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּלָא!
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira objects to Say apply it to matter of the offspring of sacrificial as enter your mind to say: Since they are sacred when they are blemished, on account of their mother, they may also be sacrificed when they are blemished. teach us not
llm_translation: Rabbi Zeira strongly objects: Say, give it a matter for the offspring of holy things, for I would say: Since the holy things, when they have blemishes, are disqualified regarding their mother, when they have blemishes, they should also be disqualified regarding their proximity. This teaches us that it is not so!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: כְּבָר פַּסְקַהּ תַּנָּא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, דְּתָנָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל: ״רַק קָדָשֶׁיךָ אֲשֶׁר יִהְיוּ לְךָ וּנְדָרֶיךָ״ — ״רַק קָדָשֶׁיךָ״ אֵלּוּ הַתְּמוּרוֹת, ״אֲשֶׁר יִהְיוּ לְךָ״ אֵלּוּ הַוְּולָדוֹת, ״וּנְדָרֶיךָ״ — הִקִּישָׁן הַכָּתוּב לְנֶדֶר, מָה נֶדֶר בַּעַל מוּם לֹא, אַף הָנֵי נָמֵי בַּעַל מוּם לֹא.
human_translation: Rava says The tanna of the school of Rabbi Yishmael has already ruled As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: “Only your sacred items which you have, and your vows, “Only your sacred items”; these are the substitutes. “Which you have”; these are the offspring. “And your vows,” juxtaposes with a vow, just as a vow not blemished, so too, these are also not blemished.
llm_translation: Rava said: A Tanna of the school of Rabbi Ishmael has already determined, as it was taught in the school of Rabbi Ishmael: "Only your consecrated things that are yours and your vows" - "Only your consecrated things" refers to substitutions, "that are yours" refers to offspring, "and your vows" - the Scripture equated them to vows; just as a blemished vow is not valid, so too these are not valid.

hebrew_text: וְאֵין עוֹשִׂין תְּמוּרָה, מַאי טַעְמָא? דְּאָמַר קְרָא: ״לֹא יַחֲלִיפֶנּוּ וְלֹא יָמִיר וְגוֹ׳״. הַשְׁתָּא רַע בְּטוֹב אָמְרַתְּ לֹא, טוֹב בְּרָע מִיבַּעְיָא? אֶלָּא טוֹב מֵעִיקָּרוֹ עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה, רַע מֵעִיקָּרוֹ אֵין עוֹשֶׂה תְּמוּרָה.
human_translation: And do not render a substitute What is the reason as the verse states: “He shall not exchange it, nor substitute it, Now you have said a bad for a good not is it necessary a good for a bad not Rather, good at the outset renders a subsitute bad at the outset, does not render a subsitute
llm_translation: And they do not make an exchange, what is the reason? As the verse says: "He shall not alter it nor change it" (Deuteronomy 21:10). Now, if it is bad for good, you say no, but good for bad, is it necessary? Rather, good from the outset makes an exchange, bad from the outset does not make an exchange.

hebrew_text: אִם מֵתוּ יִפָּדוּ. אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: זוֹ דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן, דְּאָמַר: קׇדְשֵׁי מִזְבֵּחַ הָיוּ בִּכְלַל הַעֲמָדָה וְהַעֲרָכָה, קׇדְשֵׁי בֶּדֶק הַבַּיִת לֹא הָיוּ בִּכְלַל הַעֲמָדָה וְהַעֲרָכָה.
human_translation: And if died they may be redeemed Rav Yehuda says Rav says: This is the statement of Rabbi Shimon, who says: consecrated to altar were included in standing and valuation, sanctity of Temple maintenance, were not included in standing and valuation.
llm_translation: If they died, they must be redeemed. Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: These are the words of Rabbi Shimon, who said: The holy items of the altar were included in the standing and arranging, but the holy items of the Temple courtyard were not included in the standing and arranging.

hebrew_text: דִּתְנַן, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: קׇדְשֵׁי בֶּדֶק הַבַּיִת, אִם מֵתוּ — יִפָּדוּ. וּמוֹדֶה רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בְּבַעַל מוּם מֵעִיקָּרוֹ שֶׁנִּפְדֶּה. מַאי טַעְמָא? דְּאָמַר קְרָא: ״אוֹתָהּ״ ״אוֹתָהּ״ — לְמַעוֹטֵי בַּעַל מוּם מֵעִיקָּרָא.
human_translation: as we learned Rabbi Shimon says: consecrated for the Temple maintenance, if they died they may be redeemed, And Rabbi Shimon concedes with regard to blemished from the outset, that it may be redeemed What is the reason? as the verse states: it” “it” to exclude blemished from the outset.
llm_translation: We learned in a Mishnah: Rabbi Shimon says: The consecrated animals of the Temple courtyard, if they die, they must be redeemed. And Rabbi Shimon concedes regarding an animal with a blemish from the outset that it should be redeemed. What is the reason? As the verse states: "It" "It" - to exclude an animal with a blemish from the outset.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל חֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: אִם מֵתוּ — יִקָּבֵרוּ. מַאן חֲכָמִים? תָּנָא דְּבֵי לֵוִי הוּא, דְּתָנָא דְּבֵי לֵוִי: הַכֹּל הָיוּ בִּכְלַל הַעֲמָדָה וְהַעֲרָכָה, וַאֲפִילּוּ בַּעַל מוּם מֵעִיקָּרוֹ.
human_translation: But the Rabbis say: if they died they must be buried. Whose the Rabbis tanna of the school of Levi, as the school of Levi taught: All were included in standing and valuation, even blemished from the outset.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: But the sages say: If they died — they should be buried. Who are the sages? It is the Tanna of the school of Levi, as taught by the Tanna of the school of Levi: All were included in the standing and evaluation, even a blemished one from the outset.

hebrew_text: וְכֵן תָּנָא דְּבֵי לֵוִי בְּמַתְנִיתֵיהּ: אֲפִילּוּ חַיָּה, אֲפִילּוּ עוֹף, וְהָכְתִיב ״אוֹתָהּ״! ״אוֹתָהּ״ לְתָנָא דְּבֵי לֵוִי קַשְׁיָא.
human_translation: And similarly, the school of Levi taught in baraitot : Even an undomesticated animal even a bird But isn’t it written: it,” it” difficult according to the tanna of the school of Levi.
llm_translation: And so taught the school of Levi in its Mishnah: Even a wild animal, even a bird, and it is written "her"! "Her" is difficult according to the teaching of the school of Levi.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל רַבָּנַן דִּפְלִיגִי עֲלֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן, מַאי? הָכִי נָמֵי דְּאִם מֵתוּ יִפָּדוּ? אִי הָכִי,
human_translation: But the Rabbis who disagree with Rabbi Shimon what Is it indeed so that if died they may be redeemed, If that is so,
llm_translation: But the sages who disagree with Rabbi Shimon, what? So too if they die, should they be redeemed? If so,

hebrew_text: ״זוֹ דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן וּמַחְלוּקְתּוֹ״ מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ!
human_translation: he should have This is the statement of Rabbi Shimon and those who disagree with him.
llm_translation: "This is the statement of Rabbi Shimon and his dispute!" Who asked him?

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: רַב כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ, דְּאָמַר לְרַבָּנַן: קׇדְשֵׁי בֶּדֶק הַבַּיִת הָיוּ בִּכְלַל הַעֲמָדָה וְהַעֲרָכָה, קׇדְשֵׁי מִזְבֵּחַ לֹא הָיוּ בִּכְלַל הַעֲמָדָה וְהַעֲרָכָה, וְלָא מִיתּוֹקְמָא מַתְנִיתִין כְּרַבָּנַן, דְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא: וְאִם מֵתוּ יִקָּבֵרוּ.
human_translation: said Rav in accordance with Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, who says: According to the Rabbis, consecrated for the Temple maintenance were included in standing and valuation, consecrated for the altar were not included in standing and valuation. And not interpret the mishna in accordance with the Rabbis, as the latter clause teaches: And if died, they must be buried
llm_translation: They said: Rav as Rav Shimon ben Lakish said to the Rabbis: The consecrated items of the Temple courtyard were included in the count of the standing and valuation, but the consecrated items of the altar were not included in the count of the standing and valuation. And the Mishnah does not follow the Rabbis, as it teaches in the latter part: "And if they die, they shall be buried."

hebrew_text: אָמַר: מִמַּאי דְּהָא ״מֵתוּ יִקָּבֵרוּ״ מִשּׁוּם דְּבָעֵי הַעֲמָדָה וְהַעֲרָכָה הוּא? דִּלְמָא מִשּׁוּם דְּאֵין פּוֹדִין אֶת הַקֳּדָשִׁים לְהַאֲכִילָן לִכְלָבִים הוּא! אָמְרִי: אִם כֵּן, נִיתְנֵי: ״אִם נַעֲשׂוּ טְרֵיפָה יִקָּבֵרוּ״.
human_translation: says: From where that this they died they must be buried, is due to that require standing and valuation? Perhaps it is because one may not redeem sacrificial to feed them to dogs. said If so, let teach: If them became an animal with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [ tereifa ], it must be buried.
llm_translation: He said: From where do we derive that "if they die, they shall be buried" is due to the requirements of standing and evaluation? Perhaps it is because we do not redeem consecrated items to feed them to dogs! They said: If so, let it be stated: "If they became trefah, they shall be buried."

hebrew_text: וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: לְעוֹלָם רַב כְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן סְבִירָא לֵיהּ, וּתְנִי: זוֹ דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן וּמַחְלוּקְתּוֹ.
human_translation: And if you wish, say Actually, Rav holds in accordance with Rabbi Yoḥanan, And taught: This is the statement of Rabbi Shimon and those who disagree with him.
llm_translation: And if you wish, say: Always Rav like Rabbi Yochanan, holds it, and teaches: This is the opinion of Rabbi Shimon and his dispute.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל קָדַם הֶקְדֵּשָׁן וְכוּ׳. מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי? דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״צְבִי״, מָה צְבִי פָּטוּר מִן הַבְּכוֹרָה, אַף פְּסוּלֵי הַמּוּקְדָּשִׁין פְּטוּרִין מִן הַבְּכוֹרָה.
human_translation: But their consecration preceded From where are these matters as the Sages taught gazelle Just as a gazelle is exempt firstborn, so too, disqualified consecrated are exempt firstborn.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: But the consecrated animal preceded, etc. Whence are these words? For the Rabbis taught: "A deer," just as a deer is exempt from the firstborn status, so too disqualified consecrated animals are exempt from the firstborn status.

hebrew_text: אוֹצִיא אֲנִי אֶת הַבְּכוֹרָה, וְלֹא אוֹצִיא אֶת הַמַּתָּנוֹת? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אַיָּל״, מָה אַיָּל פָּטוּר מִן הַבְּכוֹרָה וּמִן הַמַּתָּנוֹת, אַף פְּסוּלֵי הַמּוּקְדָּשִׁין פְּטוּרִין מִן הַבְּכוֹרָה וּמִן הַמַּתָּנוֹת.
